channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Bank Indonesia Official Summoned as Witness in Graft Case
item.description: A Bank Indonesia deputy governor will testify this week as a witness in a graft case related to the use of corporate social responsibility funds.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Chandra Asmara

item.title: Brazil Economists’ Shifting Calls Presage Thriller Rate Decision
item.description: On the eve of Brazil’s interest rate decision this week, XP’s Chief Economist Caio Megale agonized over data and policymaker speeches before switching his forecast to a hold from a quarter-point rise. Poring over the same details, ASA economist Leonardo Costa went the opposite way, ditching his bet on steady borrowing costs and calling for a hike instead.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Andrew Rosati

item.title: Philippine Central Bank Chief Calls Peso Intervention Futile
item.description: The Philippines will tolerate the slide in its currency to a two-month low, with the central bank governor flagging that interventions won’t be effective in the face of global risk aversion.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo, Prima Wirayani

item.title: PBOC Head Imagines New World Currency Order After Dollar Era
item.description: People’s Bank of China Governor Pan Gongsheng laid out in the clearest terms yet his vision for the future of a new global currency order after decades of dollar dominance, predicting a more competitive system will take root in the years to come.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Wenjin Lv, Yujing Liu, Zheng Li

item.title: South African Inflation Holds Steady as Conflict Clouds Outlook
item.description: South African inflation rate held steady in May as uncertainty around the outlook for price-growth mounts, complicating the task for the central bank when it meets to discuss its monetary policy stance next month.
item.dc:creator: Zinhle Xaba, Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: South Africa's consumer prices rose 2.8% from a year earlier. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF Met Emerging-Market Creditors on Debt Rework Strategies
item.description: A group of International Monetary Fund officials met with private creditors last week in London, as part of the multilateral lender’s work to publish a new report on sovereign debt restructurings in emerging markets, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jorgelina Do Rosario

media:content.media:description: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Fall meetings signage outside the IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, Oct. 20, 2024.

item.title: ECB’s Panetta Says Economic Outlook Faces Substantial Risks
item.description: The euro-zone’s economic prospects face “substantial” dangers that officials are struggling to assess, according to European Central Bank Governing Council member Fabio Panetta.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Alexander Weber

item.title: The US Has More Copper Than China But No Way to Refine All of It
item.description: The industry will need to overcome high energy and labor costs, environmental regulations and a glut of cheap Chinese competition to make US copper smelting great again.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lorinc, James Attwood, Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: Vessels and residual ore at the idled Asarco smelter in Hayden, Arizona.

item.title: Yellen, Bernanke Oppose GOP-Backed Cuts to Financial Research
item.description: Former Federal Reserve Chairs Janet Yellen and Ben Bernanke, along with several other academics, market participants and former Treasury officials, urged congressional leadership to oppose cuts to an office charged with gathering data aimed at preventing another financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Janet Yellen Photographer: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images

item.title: Modi Disputes Trump’s Version of India-Pakistan Ceasefire
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi disputed President Donald Trump’s claims that trade deals were used to clinch a ceasefire with Pakistan during last month’s military conflict.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta, Prateek Mazumdar

item.title: Riksbank Cuts Key Rate and Signals Potential for More Easing
item.description: Sweden’s central bank lowered borrowing costs by a quarter point, resuming attempts to jump-start growth in the biggest Nordic economy, and said even more easing is possible.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

item.title: UK Inflation Holds at Highest in Over a Year Before BOE Vote
item.description: UK inflation remained at its highest in over a year, keeping price pressures uncomfortably strong as the Bank of England weighs how much energy market turmoil will affect its path to cutting interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

item.title: China Car Subsidy Halted in Some Areas as Funds Run Low
item.description: China’s trade-in subsidy to boost sales of electric and fuel-efficient vehicles has been suspended in key cities across at least six provinces as funds run short and officials scrutinize the prevalence of ‘zero-mileage’ used cars.
item.dc:creator: Linda Lew

media:content.media:description: Photo by Costfoto/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

item.title: Nomura Says US to Set High Asia Tariffs to Stop China Rerouting
item.description: The US may keep elevated tariffs on Southeast Asian countries amid data suggesting that China is diverting goods through the region to avoid higher levies, according to Nomura Holdings Inc.
item.dc:creator: Claire Jiao

item.title: Thai Exports Soar Most in Three Years as Tariff Talks Begin
item.description: Thailand’s exports surged the most since early 2022 as companies rushed to stockpile goods while the Trump administration’s planned tariffs are still on hold.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Pathom Sangwongwanich

item.title: Goldman, JPMorgan Bet Strong Franc Will Shrug Off SNB Rate at 0%
item.description: Wall Street’s biggest banks are betting the Swiss franc’s strength and haven appeal will cope with the potential return of subzero interest rates in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Tajitsu

item.title: London’s Sky-High Prices Thin the Ranks of Room-to-Rent Seekers
item.description: The number of people looking for a room to rent in London has continued to slide, data from a property search website show, in a sign that high rents are pushing even that modest goal out of reach for many residents.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: BOK Warns of Inflation Risks From US Tariffs, Israel-Iran Crisis
item.description: While South Korea’s inflation has stabilized near the central bank’s 2% target, US tariffs and the Israel-Iran conflict are adding uncertainty to the outlook, according to the Bank of Korea.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: Japan to Protect Trade Interests And Not Rush Deal, Ishiba Says
item.description: Japan will prioritize protecting its national interests in trade talks without rushing into a deal with the US, Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said as he wrapped up two days of meetings at the Group of Seven gathering.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami, Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Australian PM Says EU Trade Deal Is ‘Symbolically Important’
item.description: Expanding trade ties between Australia and the European Union would be “symbolically important” in an environment of rising protectionism, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said Wednesday, as the two sides also plan talks on a defense agreement.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Japan, South Korea Pledge Closer Ties After Lee-Ishiba Meeting
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung and Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba agreed to step up cooperation in their first in-person talks, in an early indication of the direction of future relations between the two countries after Lee took office.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba, left, and Lee Jae Myung meet on the sidelines of the G-7 summit in Alberta, Canada, on June 17. Source: Yonhap News Agency

item.title: Japan’s Exports Drop Raises Recession Risks as US Tariffs Bite
item.description: Japan’s exports fell for the first time in eight months as the US tariff campaign weighed on global trade, raising the risk of a technical recession after the economy contracted at the start of the year.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Biggest Free Food Program Hobbled by India’s Dated Census Data
item.description: The government relies on old figures to shape budgets and policies.
item.dc:creator: Pratik Parija, Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: People line up to receive rations in a village on the outskirts of Kolkata.

item.title: Chile Holds Rates at 5%, Leaving Timing Open on Future Cuts
item.description: Chile’s central bank kept its interest rate unchanged and signaled it will resume cuts in coming months as long as the economic impact from global uncertainty — including the Middle East conflict — remains limited.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski, Carolina Gonzalez

item.title: Fed to Hold Rates Steady Again as Officials Wait for More Clarity on Economy
item.description: Federal Reserve officials are widely expected to leave interest rates unchanged for a fourth straight meeting on Wednesday, reiterating they want more clarity on the economic impact of a wide array of government policy changes before adjusting borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Federal Reserve officials held interest rates steady for a third-straight meeting and emphasized they see a growing risk of both higher inflation and rising unemployment.

item.title: New Zealand Plans Switch to Annual Data-Driven Census From 2030
item.description: New Zealand will drop its five-yearly census and adopt a new approach using administrative data collected across a range of government agencies from 2030.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians cross a street in the retail area of Newmarket in Auckland, New Zealand, on Saturday, Feb. 22, 2025. New Zealand’s central bank will slow the pace of interest-rate cuts after a third straight reduction of 50 basis points, saying lower borrowing costs should begin to stoke an economic recovery. Photographer: Fiona Goodall/Bloomberg

item.title: Milei Cools Argentina Wholesale Inflation to Lowest Since 2020
item.description: Argentine President Javier Milei notched another economic victory Tuesday after data showed wholesale prices declined in May for the first time since the height of the pandemic, adding to his momentum before October midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

item.title: Supreme Court Asked to Hear Challenge to Trump’s Global Tariffs
item.description: Two family-owned toy companies are asking the US Supreme Court to consider striking down many of President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs, putting a high-stakes fight with worldwide economic implications before the justices for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Monday, Oct. 4, 2021. The court's conservative wing offers a menu of opportunities to exploit its 6-3 majority, and give Republicans the type of payoff they envisioned when they pushed through Justice Amy Coney Barrett's Senate confirmation just before the 2020 election.

item.title: Harder to Cut With Core Inflation Firm, Bank of Canada Says
item.description: Bank of Canada officials said it would be tough to cut the policy interest rate further if core inflation remains firm, but acknowledged more easing may be needed if the economy continues to weaken.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg, Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Canada building in Ottawa.

item.title: Tax Bill Lacks Votes as Senate Aims for SALT, Medicaid Deals
item.description: Republican leaders are aiming for quick negotiations over needed changes to the newly unveiled Senate tax bill which lacks the votes to secure majorities in both chambers as written.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Alicia Diaz, Steven T. Dennis
